rule.name: For ten points
rule.example: Instead, the mystery on Grimden Moor continues through the final chapter. For ten points, name this most famous of the novels.

rule.name: for 10 points
rule.message: Don’t interject “for 10 points” in the middle of a sentence.
rule.example: Voting could not be done by those who had, for 10 points, what demographic trait possessed by around 50% of ancient Rome's population?
For 10 points, name this core sugar found in RNA.

If these objects satisfy the Dirichlet boundary conditions, they are prefixed with a capital letter D. For 10 points, name these mathematical objects used in M-theory that generalize the concept of a string to higher dimensions.

This “teacher of Germany” authored a set of 28 articles that affirmed the “real presence” in the Eucharist, but denied salvation by works, to be presented at a meeting convened by Charles V. For 10 points, name this author of the Augsburg Confession, a Lutheran reformer with a Latinate name.

rule.name: Relative time
rule.message: Did you mean to use \1 instead of an absolute time phrase?
rule.example: A more recent art project saw him send his un-literary prime minister a book every fortnight, from The Death of Ivan Ilyich to A Modest Proposal, with a letter explaining the choice, resulting in the compilation, “What is Stephen Harper Reading?”
This author recently wrote a novel, Scribbler Moon, for the Future Library project, and will contribute a set of cartoons to the upcoming anthology The Secret Loves of Geek Girls.

rule.name: Ranges
rule.message: Don’t use en-dashes or hyphens for ranges.
rule.example: from 1910 to 1928

rule.name: Dashes
rule.message: Use typographically correct (special) characters and prefer spaced en dashes so that words are always separated by spaces.
rule.example: Track A—Solo Dancer
Track A — Solo Dancer
Track A–Solo Dancer
Track A--Solo Dancer
Track A -- Solo Dancer
Track A – Solo Dancer
That novel from this country ends with the protagonist “sagg[ing] down” after saying “I can feel it coming up under my feet, up my legs—.”

rule.message: Three answerline references use “\1 \2”. Consider using a more specific term.
rule.example: Henry Morton Robinson and Joseph Campbell wrote a “skeleton key” to this work, from which Campbell borrowed the term “monomyth.” ... For 10 points, the line "riverrun, past Eve and Adam’s” opens what final novel by James Joyce?
A character in this work screams “DAMN MY EGGS” and (*) “FLAMING SPEAR! HOT DAMN!” while standing on a table.

rule.message: Did you mean to use \1 \2 to describe the answer? Consider using a more specific term.
rule.example: The abbreviation USSR stands for the “union” of these polities. ANSWER: Soviet socialist republics [prompt on partial answer].
This polity's forces requisitioned sleighs from its citizens to cut off an invading army's escape in the Great Sleigh Drive

rule.message: Future-in-the-past is unnecessarily complicated (pretentious? flowery? literary?). Use simple past instead: clear and direct. (dry? stuffy? more neutral?)
rule.example: At this war’s Battle of Lutter, the forces of Christian IV were defeated by a commander whose troops would later sack the city of (*) Magdeburg.

rule.message: Future-in-the-past is unnecessarily complicated (pretentious? flowery? literary?). Use simple past instead: clear and direct. (dry? stuffy? more neutral?)
rule.example: This angel, later to become Satan, leads the initial revolt against God.
This Boer general during the war won the Battle of Colenso and later became the first Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa in 1910.

rule.message: Future-in-the-past is unnecessarily complicated (pretentious? flowery? literary?). Use simple past instead: clear and direct. (dry? stuffy? more neutral?)
rule.example: Clovis established the Merovingian capital in this city. This city would go on to be the capital of France.
